elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with high porosity and good stability are a booming class of adsorbent materials exhibiting extensive gas adsorption and separation. In this work, a polyhedral heterometallic MOF, [InCu2(CBDA)2(H2O)2]·n(solvent) (In/Cu-CBDA) [CBDA = 5,5′-(carbonylbis­(azanediyl))-diisophthalic acid], on the basis of tetracarboxylic ligand, has been successfully obtained by one-step synthesis. Based on the theory of hard and soft acid–base (HSAB), the formation of strong coordination bonds (high-valency In-carboxylate) results in excellent stability of In/Cu-CBDA when heated at 150 °C, exposured to the air, and soaked in the organic solvents. By utilizing a supermolecular building block (SBB) strategy, the coordination between isophthalate moieties and Cu­(II) paddlewheels provides a platform for assembly of a metal–organic polyhedron (MOP), so that the In/Cu-CBDA displays permanent porosity and high adsorption selectivity of CO2/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 as predicted by IAST. This work affords an idea to design and synthesize target MOF materials for broad possibilities in advanced applications through a combination of HSAB theory and SBB strategy.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with high porosity and good stability are a booming class of adsorbent materials exhibiting extensive gas adsorption and separation. In this work, a polyhedral heterometallic MOF, [InCu2(CBDA)2(H2O)2]⋅n(solvent) (In/Cu-CBDA) [CBDA = 5,5'-(carbonylbis(azanediyl))-diisophthalic acid], on the basis of tetracarboxylic ligand, has been successfully obtained by one-step synthesis. Based on the theory of hard and soft acid-base (HSAB), the formation of strong coordination bonds (high-valency In-carboxylate) results in excellent stability of In/Cu-CBDA when heated at 150 °C, exposured to the air, and soaked in the organic solvents. By utilizing a supermolecular building block (SBB) strategy, the coordination between isophthalate moieties and Cu(II) paddlewheels provides a platform for assembly of a metal-organic polyhedron (MOP), so that the In/Cu-CBDA displays permanent porosity and high adsorption selectivity of CO2/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4 as predicted by IAST. This work affords an idea to design and synthesize target MOF materials for broad possibilities in advanced applications through a combination of HSAB theory and SBB strategy.

elements.content: A polyhedral heterometallic MOF In/Cu-CBDA has already been obtained by a one-step synthesis based on the hard and soft acid−base theory and supermolecular building block strategy. In/Cu-CBDA has good stability and permanent porosity, which displays highly selective adsorption of CO2/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4.
elements.clean_text: A polyhedral heterometallic MOF In/Cu-CBDA has already been obtained by a one-step synthesis based on the hard and soft acid-base theory and supermolecular building block strategy. In/Cu-CBDA has good stability and permanent porosity, which displays highly selective adsorption of CO2/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of crystal porous material, have a wide application prospect in practical applications because of their predictable structure, large specific surface area, high porosity, controllable pore size, and functionalization of pore surface. The stability of MOFs is greatly challenged under the strict conditions, which ultimately is difficult to have any practical application value. Hence, not only structural characteristics but also the stability of MOFs play a key role in practical applications, such as gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical sensing, biometric imaging and drug release, and proton conduction. The MOFs designed by the theory of hard and soft acid–base (HSAB principle) shows excellent stability. Based on this theory, some representative stable MOFs are obtained, such as high-valency metal-carboxylate frameworks (PCN-600 and MIL-100 (Fe), UiO-66, MIL-53 (Cr)) and low-valency metal-azolate frameworks (ZIF-8, M3(BTP)2 (M = Ni, Cu, Zn, Co), MAF-X25).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an emerging class of crystal porous material, have a wide application prospect in practical applications because of their predictable structure, large specific surface area, high porosity, controllable pore size, and functionalization of pore surface. The stability of MOFs is greatly challenged under the strict conditions, which ultimately is difficult to have any practical application value. Hence, not only structural characteristics but also the stability of MOFs play a key role in practical applications, such as gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, chemical sensing, biometric imaging and drug release, and proton conduction. The MOFs designed by the theory of hard and soft acid-base (HSAB principle) shows excellent stability. Based on this theory, some representative stable MOFs are obtained, such as high-valency metal-carboxylate frameworks (PCN-600 and MIL-100 (Fe), UiO-66, MIL-53 (Cr)) and low-valency metal-azolate frameworks (ZIF-8, M3(BTP)2 (M = Ni, Cu, Zn, Co), MAF-X25).

elements.content: The ligands containing isophthalate moieties constructed with paddlewheels afford a platform for assembling a metal–organic polyhedron (MOP), which can be regarded as a supermolecular building block (SBB) to design and synthesize polyhedron-based MOF (PMOF) materials. The structure characteristics of PMOFs with a large-void cage interconnected through a small-sized window give them an opportunity to apply to gas adsorption and separation by a sieving effect. Based on this design idea, an increasing number of PMOF materials have been obtained, which exhibit outstanding CO2 capture and selective gas separation capabilities. With the increasing topological structure and high-performance requirement of MOFs, many researchers devote themselves to developing heterometallic systems to achieve the goal of constructing ideal target MOF materials. Due to the introduction of heterometallics, they respectively take an active role in MOFs to acquire amazing structure and satisfactory performance.
elements.clean_text: The ligands containing isophthalate moieties constructed with paddlewheels afford a platform for assembling a metal-organic polyhedron (MOP), which can be regarded as a supermolecular building block (SBB) to design and synthesize polyhedron-based MOF (PMOF) materials. The structure characteristics of PMOFs with a large-void cage interconnected through a small-sized window give them an opportunity to apply to gas adsorption and separation by a sieving effect. Based on this design idea, an increasing number of PMOF materials have been obtained, which exhibit outstanding CO2 capture and selective gas separation capabilities. With the increasing topological structure and high-performance requirement of MOFs, many researchers devote themselves to developing heterometallic systems to achieve the goal of constructing ideal target MOF materials. Due to the introduction of heterometallics, they respectively take an active role in MOFs to acquire amazing structure and satisfactory performance.

elements.content: On the basis of the aforementioned considerations, the tetracarboxylic ligand CBDA [CBDA = 5,5′-(carbonylbis­(azanediyl))-diisophthalic acid] becomes our preferable object because of (1) the optimum size of linker guarantee synergetic for the kinetic stability and large surface area; (2) isophthalate moieties are one of the necessary conditions for construction of PMOFs; (3) the carboxylate group constructed with high-valency metal to form strong coordination bond; and (4) the urea functional group (−NH–CO–NH) can be an acting site to strengthen the interaction between framework and gas molecules. Furthermore, on the one hand, high-valence metal ions In3+ are selected as hard acids constructed with a carboxylate group as hard bases to form stable MOFs. On the other hand, Cu paddlewheels are designated to build with isophthalate moieties for assembling a MOP architecture (). As expected, we have achieved a polyhedral heterometallic MOF In/Cu-CBDA. It does have the marvelous three-dimensional (3D) skeleton structure and good stability. It is worth noting that In/Cu-CBDA has permanent pores, which provides a powerful impetus for the study of gas absorption and separation characteristics. Herein, we wish to present the one-pot preparation, structural characterization, and selective CO2, C2H6, and C3H8 over CH4 adsorption properties of the resulting In/Cu-CBDA, with the focus on exploring the positive synergy of heterometallics on the structural stabilities and selective adsorption properties.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the aforementioned considerations, the tetracarboxylic ligand CBDA [CBDA = 5,5'-(carbonylbis(azanediyl))-diisophthalic acid] becomes our preferable object because of (1) the optimum size of linker guarantee synergetic for the kinetic stability and large surface area; (2) isophthalate moieties are one of the necessary conditions for construction of PMOFs; (3) the carboxylate group constructed with high-valency metal to form strong coordination bond; and (4) the urea functional group (-NH-CO-NH) can be an acting site to strengthen the interaction between framework and gas molecules. Furthermore, on the one hand, high-valence metal ions In3+ are selected as hard acids constructed with a carboxylate group as hard bases to form stable MOFs. On the other hand, Cu paddlewheels are designated to build with isophthalate moieties for assembling a MOP architecture (). As expected, we have achieved a polyhedral heterometallic MOF In/Cu-CBDA. It does have the marvelous three-dimensional (3D) skeleton structure and good stability. It is worth noting that In/Cu-CBDA has permanent pores, which provides a powerful impetus for the study of gas absorption and separation characteristics. Herein, we wish to present the one-pot preparation, structural characterization, and selective CO2, C2H6, and C3H8 over CH4 adsorption properties of the resulting In/Cu-CBDA, with the focus on exploring the positive synergy of heterometallics on the structural stabilities and selective adsorption properties.

elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of Rational Design for a Stable Polyhedral Heterometallic MOF

elements.content: The chemicals involved were purchased from formal commercial sources and used without extra purification operations. First, on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer accompanied by Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were gathered. Second, on a vario MICRO elementary analyzer, elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed. Third, on a TGA Q500 thermogravimetric analyzer, the thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed. Finally, on Quantachrome autosorb iQ, gas adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured. Crystallographic data was collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The structure of In/Cu-CBDA was solved by the direct method using SHELXTL and then refined using the SHELX-2013 program based on the full-matrix least-squares method. Table S1 lists detailed crystallization data for In/Cu-CBDA. Bond lengths [Å] and angles [°] are listed in Table S2 as well. Crystallographic data for In/Cu-CBDA (1888174) has been provided by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Topology information on the compound was calculated by TOPOS 4.0. 100 mg of as-synthesized samples of In/Cu-CBDA as raw materials were exchanged with acetone for 4 d by reflux process, then evacuated for 10 h under dynamic vacuum at 373 K to ensure that the guest solvent molecules are removed. The obtained activated samples were used for N2, CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 gas adsorption tests. The temperature at 77 K was maintained due to using liquid nitrogen, and the temperatures at 273 and 298 K were controlled by a circulating bath.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The chemicals involved were purchased from formal commercial sources and used without extra purification operations. First, on a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer accompanied by Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were gathered. Second, on a vario MICRO elementary analyzer, elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed. Third, on a TGA Q500 thermogravimetric analyzer, the thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed. Finally, on Quantachrome autosorb iQ, gas adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured. Crystallographic data was collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The structure of In/Cu-CBDA was solved by the direct method using SHELXTL and then refined using the SHELX-2013 program based on the full-matrix least-squares method. Table S1 lists detailed crystallization data for In/Cu-CBDA. Bond lengths [Å] and angles [°] are listed in Table S2 as well. Crystallographic data for In/Cu-CBDA (1888174) has been provided by the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Topology information on the compound was calculated by TOPOS 4.0. 100 mg of as-synthesized samples of In/Cu-CBDA as raw materials were exchanged with acetone for 4 d by reflux process, then evacuated for 10 h under dynamic vacuum at 373 K to ensure that the guest solvent molecules are removed. The obtained activated samples were used for N2, CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 gas adsorption tests. The temperature at 77 K was maintained due to using liquid nitrogen, and the temperatures at 273 and 298 K were controlled by a circulating bath.

elements.content: The mixture of In­(NO3)3·4H2O (10 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cu­(NO3)3·3H2O (8 mg, 0.03 mmol), CBDA (4 mg, 0.01 mmol), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 0.5 mL), N-methylformamide (NMF, 0.5 mL), deionized water (H2O, 0.5 mL) and HNO3 (350 uL, 2.8 mL 18 mol L–1 HNO3 in 10 mL DMA) was sealed in a glass bottle and then heated in the oven at 90 °C for 24 h. After finishing this series of operations, the blue block-shaped crystals of In/Cu-CBDA were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried (yield: 73%, based on CBDA). It is worth mentioning that one-pot solvothermal synthesis of In/Cu-CBDA must consist of three types of solvents DMF, NMF, and H2O. Any combination of these two solvents (DMF-NMF, DMF-H2O, NMF-H2O) does not give rise to the product. Hence, the reaction solvent is of vital importance for one-pot solvothermal synthesis of heterometallic MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of In/Cu-CBDA 

The mixture of In(NO3)3⋅4H2O (10 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cu(NO3)3⋅3H2O (8 mg, 0.03 mmol), CBDA (4 mg, 0.01 mmol), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 0.5 mL), N-methylformamide (NMF, 0.5 mL), deionized water (H2O, 0.5 mL) and HNO3 (350 uL, 2.8 mL 18 mol L-1 HNO3 in 10 mL DMA) was sealed in a glass bottle and then heated in the oven at 90 °C for 24 h. After finishing this series of operations, the blue block-shaped crystals of In/Cu-CBDA were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried (yield: 73%, based on CBDA). It is worth mentioning that one-pot solvothermal synthesis of In/Cu-CBDA must consist of three types of solvents DMF, NMF, and H2O. Any combination of these two solvents (DMF-NMF, DMF-H2O, NMF-H2O) does not give rise to the product. Hence, the reaction solvent is of vital importance for one-pot solvothermal synthesis of heterometallic MOFs.

elements.content: By single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, it was revealed that In/Cu-CBDA features a three-dimensional (3D) network and crystallizes in the cubic crystal system with the space group of Im3̅m with a cell parameter a = 31.3315 Å. As depicted in a, each indium ion exhibits an eight-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry, binding with eight O atoms from four independent L4– ligands; each copper ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms which come from four different carboxylate groups and one oxygen atom belonging to the terminal water molecule, representing a square-pyramidal geometry. As expected, two neighboring copper ions were connected with each other by four carboxylate groups to form a Cu­(II) paddlewheel secondary building unit (SBU). In the coordinative environment of C 2s symmetric L4– ligand, it utilizes a half carboxylate group to chelate an In3+ ion, while the other half of the carboxylate group bonds the Cu­(II) paddlewheel SBU. They are established the classic 4-connected M­(COO)4 (M = In, Cu) moiety with tetrahedron and quadrangle geometries, respectively. These inorganic heterometallic In­(COO)4 and paddlewheel units are further linked by the organic ligands L4–, eventually leading to the formation of a complicated 3D network. Noteworthy, a close inspection of the crystal structure reveals that there are two types of MOP cages with different compositions in the overall network. As illustrated in b–d, a flattened octahedral cage A consists of four In­(COO)4, two paddlewheel units, and 12 organic ligands; a cuboctahedral cage B consists of six paddlewheel units and 12 organic ligands. Cages A and B interconnect alternately to extend a one-dimensional (1D) MOP chain, and then MOP packing arrangements result in a 3D network. The sizes of the polyhedron representing the void of the cages A–B were estimated to be about 15.7 × 7.4 Å2 and 18.8 × 18.8 Å2 (considering van der Waals radii), respectively. The PLATON calculation using a probe radius of 1.2 Å shows that a total solvent accessible volume for In/Cu-CBDA is approximately 74.6% of the cell volume, indicating its significant porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Descriptions

By single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, it was revealed that In/Cu-CBDA features a three-dimensional (3D) network and crystallizes in the cubic crystal system with the space group of Im3̅m with a cell parameter a = 31.3315 Å. As depicted in a, each indium ion exhibits an eight-coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry, binding with eight O atoms from four independent L4- ligands; each copper ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms which come from four different carboxylate groups and one oxygen atom belonging to the terminal water molecule, representing a square-pyramidal geometry. As expected, two neighboring copper ions were connected with each other by four carboxylate groups to form a Cu(II) paddlewheel secondary building unit (SBU). In the coordinative environment of C 2s  symmetric L4- ligand, it utilizes a half carboxylate group to chelate an In3+ ion, while the other half of the carboxylate group bonds the Cu(II) paddlewheel SBU. They are established the classic 4-connected M(COO)4 (M = In, Cu) moiety with tetrahedron and quadrangle geometries, respectively. These inorganic heterometallic In(COO)4 and paddlewheel units are further linked by the organic ligands L4-, eventually leading to the formation of a complicated 3D network. Noteworthy, a close inspection of the crystal structure reveals that there are two types of MOP cages with different compositions in the overall network. As illustrated in b-d, a flattened octahedral cage A consists of four In(COO)4, two paddlewheel units, and 12 organic ligands; a cuboctahedral cage B consists of six paddlewheel units and 12 organic ligands. Cages A and B interconnect alternately to extend a one-dimensional (1D) MOP chain, and then MOP packing arrangements result in a 3D network. The sizes of the polyhedron representing the void of the cages A-B were estimated to be about 15.7 × 7.4 Å2 and 18.8 × 18.8 Å2 (considering van der Waals radii), respectively. The PLATON calculation using a probe radius of 1.2 Å shows that a total solvent accessible volume for In/Cu-CBDA is approximately 74.6% of the cell volume, indicating its significant porosity.

elements.content: Single-crystal structure for In/Cu-CBDA. (a) Heterometallic SBUs [In­(COO)4] and [Cu2(COO)4], the organic ligand CBDA. (b) Two types of MOP cages with different compositions. (c) 1D MOP chain. (d) Ball–stick model of the 3D network. (e) Double helical chain.
elements.clean_text: 1  Single-crystal structure for In/Cu-CBDA. (a) Heterometallic SBUs [In(COO)4] and [Cu2(COO)4], the organic ligand CBDA. (b) Two types of MOP cages with different compositions. (c) 1D MOP chain. (d) Ball-stick model of the 3D network. (e) Double helical chain.

elements.content: Topologically, the In­(COO)4 and paddlewheel unit are taken as four-connected nodes. If a ligand is regarded as a four-connected node, then the overall structure can be simplified as a four-connected network with nbo topology (the point symbol is (64·82)). Alternately, the ligand is considered as a three-connected node, and the (3,4,4) connected network adopts a new topology (the point symbol is (72·9)2(74·82)) (Figure S2). Interestingly, the structure has two types of helical chains with opposite helical directions (left- and right-handed). The repetitive unit of helical chain contains three In­(COO)4 units and three ligands L4–, and the corresponding a pitch is 27.1 Å (e).
elements.clean_text: Topologically, the In(COO)4 and paddlewheel unit are taken as four-connected nodes. If a ligand is regarded as a four-connected node, then the overall structure can be simplified as a four-connected network with nbo topology (the point symbol is (64⋅82)). Alternately, the ligand is considered as a three-connected node, and the (3,4,4) connected network adopts a new topology (the point symbol is (72⋅9)2(74⋅82)) (Figure S2). Interestingly, the structure has two types of helical chains with opposite helical directions (left- and right-handed). The repetitive unit of helical chain contains three In(COO)4 units and three ligands L4-, and the corresponding a pitch is 27.1 Å (e).

elements.content: The diffraction peaks position of the powder XRD spectrum of the compound obtained from the experiments are in good agreement with the simulated ones, indicating the synthesized compounds are pure phase (Figure S3). Next, the diffraction peaks of the experimental XRD spectra of the synthetic samples immersed in different solvents with low boiling points (acetone, acetonitrile, acetone, and methanol), exposed to air at room temperature for 24 h and 7 days and heated up to 150 °C air atmosphere for 5 h are consistent with the simulated spectra. Furthermore, in order to give more accurate information about the chemical stability of the framework, a C3H8 adsorption measurement has been tested before and after exposure to air (d and Figure S6). The maximum adsorption capacity is very close. It is proved that the crystal structure has outstanding stability in different organic solvents, air atmosphere, and high temperature. The presented good stability of framework is due to the strong coordination bond In-COOH based on HSAB theory ( and Figure S4). In addition, thermogravimetry is another method to characterize structural stability. It is the thermogravimetric curve of In/Cu-CBDA under the atmospheric environment (Figure S5). TGA of In/Cu-CBDA shows that the compound weightlessness can be divided into two steps. The first step of weightlessness is between 30 and 142 °C, and the weight loss rate is about 37.7%. Weight loss at this stage is mainly attributed to the removal of guest molecules and coordination water molecules. Then continual heat results in the collapse of the framework of the compound and the high thermal decomposition of the organic ligands, and the weight loss is about 23.1%.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization and Properties of In/Cu-CBDA 

The diffraction peaks position of the powder XRD spectrum of the compound obtained from the experiments are in good agreement with the simulated ones, indicating the synthesized compounds are pure phase (Figure S3). Next, the diffraction peaks of the experimental XRD spectra of the synthetic samples immersed in different solvents with low boiling points (acetone, acetonitrile, acetone, and methanol), exposed to air at room temperature for 24 h and 7 days and heated up to 150 °C air atmosphere for 5 h are consistent with the simulated spectra. Furthermore, in order to give more accurate information about the chemical stability of the framework, a C3H8 adsorption measurement has been tested before and after exposure to air (d and Figure S6). The maximum adsorption capacity is very close. It is proved that the crystal structure has outstanding stability in different organic solvents, air atmosphere, and high temperature. The presented good stability of framework is due to the strong coordination bond In-COOH based on HSAB theory ( and Figure S4). In addition, thermogravimetry is another method to characterize structural stability. It is the thermogravimetric curve of In/Cu-CBDA under the atmospheric environment (Figure S5). TGA of In/Cu-CBDA shows that the compound weightlessness can be divided into two steps. The first step of weightlessness is between 30 and 142 °C, and the weight loss rate is about 37.7%. Weight loss at this stage is mainly attributed to the removal of guest molecules and coordination water molecules. Then continual heat results in the collapse of the framework of the compound and the high thermal decomposition of the organic ligands, and the weight loss is about 23.1%.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of In/Cu-CBDA showing the framework purity and stability after treated under different conditions: heat at 150 °C, exposure to air, and soaked in different organic solvents.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns of In/Cu-CBDA showing the framework purity and stability after treated under different conditions: heat at 150 °C, exposure to air, and soaked in different organic solvents.

elements.content: To characterize the permanent porosity property of In/Cu-CBDA, we operated the N2 adsorption and desorption test at the temperature of 77 K. Before the gas adsorption experiment, we pretreated the as-synthesized sample. First, the low boiling point organic solvent acetone was used to obtain the acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA, ensuring that the high boiling point solvents in the structure were replaced completely by acetone. Second, the samples of acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA were withdrawn under dynamic vacuum heat at 90 °C for 10 h to get the activated In/Cu-CBDA. As shown in , the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of In/Cu-CBDA express a typical type-I adsorption curve which proves its microporous property. The absorption capacity of saturated N2 is 302 cm3 (STP) g–1, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir specific surface areas are calculated to be 990 and 1169 m2 g–1, respectively. The BET surface area of In/Cu-CBDA is lower than PMOFs based on a CBDA ligand and Cu paddlewheel, such as JLU-Liu46-47 (1787 and 1800 m2 g–1), but significantly higher than many heterometallic MOFs In/Tb-CBDA (782 m2 g–1), [In3O­(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]·n(solv) (In/Pd, 795 m2 g–1) and BUT-52 (In/Cu, 358 m2 g–1). The theoretical pore volume is 1.13 cm3/g, calculated based on the crystal structure. However, the experimental pore volume (0.47 cm3/g) is relatively low. This may be attributed to the fact that the partial window size of the cage structure is too small, which hinders the exchange of guest molecules with EtOH, resulting in an incomplete sample activation.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption and Separation of In/Cu-CBDA 

To characterize the permanent porosity property of In/Cu-CBDA, we operated the N2 adsorption and desorption test at the temperature of 77 K. Before the gas adsorption experiment, we pretreated the as-synthesized sample. First, the low boiling point organic solvent acetone was used to obtain the acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA, ensuring that the high boiling point solvents in the structure were replaced completely by acetone. Second, the samples of acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA were withdrawn under dynamic vacuum heat at 90 °C for 10 h to get the activated In/Cu-CBDA. As shown in , the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of In/Cu-CBDA express a typical type-I adsorption curve which proves its microporous property. The absorption capacity of saturated N2 is 302 cm3 (STP) g-1, and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir specific surface areas are calculated to be 990 and 1169 m2 g-1, respectively. The BET surface area of In/Cu-CBDA is lower than PMOFs based on a CBDA ligand and Cu paddlewheel, such as JLU-Liu46-47 (1787 and 1800 m2 g-1), but significantly higher than many heterometallic MOFs In/Tb-CBDA (782 m2 g-1), [In3O(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]⋅n(solv) (In/Pd, 795 m2 g-1) and BUT-52 (In/Cu, 358 m2 g-1). The theoretical pore volume is 1.13 cm3/g, calculated based on the crystal structure. However, the experimental pore volume (0.47 cm3/g) is relatively low. This may be attributed to the fact that the partial window size of the cage structure is too small, which hinders the exchange of guest molecules with EtOH, resulting in an incomplete sample activation.

elements.content: N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of In/Cu-CBDA and the pore size distribution calculated using the NLDFT method (STP = standard temperature and pressure).
elements.clean_text: 3  N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of In/Cu-CBDA and the pore size distribution calculated using the NLDFT method (STP = standard temperature and pressure).

elements.content: Establishment of the permanent porosity and structure feature of In/Cu-CBDA inspires us to further explore its application in selective gas adsorption and separation. Accordingly, the pure component adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 for In/Cu-CBDA were measured systematically at 273 and 298 K (pressure up to 1 atm). As shown in , all adsorption and desorption isotherms are completely reversible and with no significant hysteresis. As a result of exothermic physical adsorption, the uptake of each gas increases with the decreasing temperature. The maximum adsorption capacity of In/Cu-CBDA for CO2 is 76 and 40 cm3 g–1; CH4 is 12 and 6 cm3 g–1; C2H6 is 114 and 67 cm3 g–1; and C3H8 is 127 and 112 cm3 g–1, respectively. The difference uptake capacity of In/Cu-CBDA for different gases mainly depends on the strength of the gas–framework interaction. The isosteric heat (Q st) of gases was calculated based on the isotherms recorded at 273 and 298 K to quantify the affinity of In/Cu-CBDA for every gas molecules. At near zero coverage, the Q st values of CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 are 23.7, 13.6, 30.9, and 37.2 kJ mol–1, respectively (Figure S7). The result shows that Q st values follow the order of C3H8 > C2H6 > CO2 > CH4, corresponding to the order of the strength of the gas–framework interaction.
elements.clean_text: Establishment of the permanent porosity and structure feature of In/Cu-CBDA inspires us to further explore its application in selective gas adsorption and separation. Accordingly, the pure component adsorption isotherms of CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 for In/Cu-CBDA were measured systematically at 273 and 298 K (pressure up to 1 atm). As shown in , all adsorption and desorption isotherms are completely reversible and with no significant hysteresis. As a result of exothermic physical adsorption, the uptake of each gas increases with the decreasing temperature. The maximum adsorption capacity of In/Cu-CBDA for CO2 is 76 and 40 cm3 g-1; CH4 is 12 and 6 cm3 g-1; C2H6 is 114 and 67 cm3 g-1; and C3H8 is 127 and 112 cm3 g-1, respectively. The difference uptake capacity of In/Cu-CBDA for different gases mainly depends on the strength of the gas-framework interaction. The isosteric heat (Q st) of gases was calculated based on the isotherms recorded at 273 and 298 K to quantify the affinity of In/Cu-CBDA for every gas molecules. At near zero coverage, the Q st values of CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8 are 23.7, 13.6, 30.9, and 37.2 kJ mol-1, respectively (Figure S7). The result shows that Q st values follow the order of C3H8 > C2H6 > CO2 > CH4, corresponding to the order of the strength of the gas-framework interaction.

elements.content: (a) CO2, (b) CH4, (c) C2H6, and (d) C3H8 gas sorption isotherms for In/Tb-CBDA at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) CO2, (b) CH4, (c) C2H6, and (d) C3H8 gas sorption isotherms for In/Tb-CBDA at 273 and 298 K under 1 bar.

elements.content: Natural gas as a sustainable clean energy is mainly composed of methane, but the impurities (such as CO2, C2H6, C3H8) greatly reduce its conversion efficiency. Therefore, natural gas purification is undoubtedly essential for high-efficiency utilization. Compared with the traditional low-temperature distillation method, the use of an adsorbent has greatly reduced the energy consumption and saved on the cost. Recently, porous MOFs based on the adsorbent separation technology have been widely considered as a low-energy and high-efficient CH4 storage and separation material. Therefore, our group is committed to developing efficient porous MOFs in order to purify natural gas for many years. The obtained adsorbent material In/Cu-CBDA has the grade of uptake capacity and Q st for CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8, which provides strong evidence for In/Cu-CBDA as an adsorbent for purifying natural gas. In order to evaluate the separation capacity of CO2, C2H6, and C3H8 over CH4, we picked the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) model to predict the adsorption selectivity of the binary gas mixtures CO2/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4. Due to the fact that the maximum adsorption capacity of In/Cu-CBDA for CH4 is only 6 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, we could not fit the CO2 isotherm data at 298 K to any of the model equations. Therefore, the adsorption isotherms of the pure component at 273 K were selected to fit with the Langmuir–Freundlich equation. The fitting parameters obtained are provided in Table S4 and used for the estimate of separation performance by IAST. As shown in , it certainly reveals that the adsorption selectivity is closely related to the pressure. As the total gas pressure increases, the adsorption selectivities decrease. The selectivity of CO2/CH4 (50 and 50%; 5 and 95%) is 7.3 and 7 at atmospheric pressure. It should be noted that these values are greatly higher than ZJNU-59, 63, and 84 (7.9, 4.2, 7.2, 50, and 50%) (Table S3) under similar measurement conditions. Similarly, the adsorption selectivities of molar mixtures of C2H6/CH4 and C3H8/CH4 (50% and 50%) reach 25.3 and 191.6 at atmospheric pressure. The adsorption selectivity for a large number of MOFs has been summarized in Table S3. The comparison results indicate that In/Cu-CBDA shows more efficient selective separation of CH4 than many reported MOFs, such as UPC-33 (6.64 and 151.5) under the same conditions. The highly efficient CH4 separation of In/Cu-CBDA can be attributed to the match of the framework pore size with the kinetic diameter of gas molecules, molecular polarity, and so on. Owing to the considerable adsorption selectivity, high uptake capacity, and good stability, In/Cu-CBDA could be a promising solid adsorbent applied in the purification of natural gas.

Therefore, natural gas purification is undoubtedly essential for high-efficiency utilization. Compared with the traditional low-temperature distillation method, the use of an adsorbent has greatly reduced the energy consumption and saved on the cost. Recently, porous MOFs based on the adsorbent separation technology have been widely considered as a low-energy and high-efficient CH4 storage and separation material. Therefore, our group is committed to developing efficient porous MOFs in order to purify natural gas for many years. The obtained adsorbent material In/Cu-CBDA has the grade of uptake capacity and Q st for CO2, CH4, C2H6, and C3H8, which provides strong evidence for In/Cu-CBDA as an adsorbent for purifying natural gas. In order to evaluate the separation capacity of CO2, C2H6, and C3H8 over CH4, we picked the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) model to predict the adsorption selectivity of the binary gas mixtures CO2/CH4, C2H6/CH4, and C3H8/CH4. Due to the fact that the maximum adsorption capacity of In/Cu-CBDA for CH4 is only 6 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, we could not fit the CO2 isotherm data at 298 K to any of the model equations. Therefore, the adsorption isotherms of the pure component at 273 K were selected to fit with the Langmuir-Freundlich equation. The fitting parameters obtained are provided in Table S4 and used for the estimate of separation performance by IAST. As shown in , it certainly reveals that the adsorption selectivity is closely related to the pressure. As the total gas pressure increases, the adsorption selectivities decrease. The selectivity of CO2/CH4 (50 and 50%; 5 and 95%) is 7.3 and 7 at atmospheric pressure. It should be noted that these values are greatly higher than ZJNU-59, 63, and 84 (7.9, 4.2, 7.2, 50, and 50%) (Table S3) under similar measurement conditions. Similarly, the adsorption selectivities of molar mixtures of C2H6/CH4 and C3H8/CH4 (50% and 50%) reach 25.3 and 191.6 at atmospheric pressure. The adsorption selectivity for a large number of MOFs has been summarized in Table S3. The comparison results indicate that In/Cu-CBDA shows more efficient selective separation of CH4 than many reported MOFs, such as UPC-33 (6.64 and 151.5) under the same conditions. The highly efficient CH4 separation of In/Cu-CBDA can be attributed to the match of the framework pore size with the kinetic diameter of gas molecules, molecular polarity, and so on. Owing to the considerable adsorption selectivity, high uptake capacity, and good stability, In/Cu-CBDA could be a promising solid adsorbent applied in the purification of natural gas.

elements.content: In summary, by utilizing the powerful HSAB theory and SBBs strategy, a novel polyhedral heterometallic MOF In/Cu-CBDA has been designed and obtained by a one-step synthesis. On the one hand, the formation of a strong coordination bond, high-valency In-carboxylate ensures the framework exhibits a good stability. On the other hand, the assembled MOP by Cu paddlewheels and isophthalate moieties guarantees the framework has a large-void cage and small-size window. It makes In/Cu-CBDA display a permanent porosity and excellent selective gas adsorption performance, which is expected to be an underlying adsorbed material for purification natural gas. With the increasing requirement for MOF stability and broad possibilities for advanced applications, constant efforts are made to focus on heterometallic MOFs because of their excellent synergistic effects on the structure-stability application relationship. We believe that heterometallic MOF materials will flourish in the future and hope an increasing number of chemists work in this area.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, by utilizing the powerful HSAB theory and SBBs strategy, a novel polyhedral heterometallic MOF In/Cu-CBDA has been designed and obtained by a one-step synthesis. On the one hand, the formation of a strong coordination bond, high-valency In-carboxylate ensures the framework exhibits a good stability. On the other hand, the assembled MOP by Cu paddlewheels and isophthalate moieties guarantees the framework has a large-void cage and small-size window. It makes In/Cu-CBDA display a permanent porosity and excellent selective gas adsorption performance, which is expected to be an underlying adsorbed material for purification natural gas. With the increasing requirement for MOF stability and broad possibilities for advanced applications, constant efforts are made to focus on heterometallic MOFs because of their excellent synergistic effects on the structure-stability application relationship. We believe that heterometallic MOF materials will flourish in the future and hope an increasing number of chemists work in this area.

cln_elements.content: The mixture of In­(NO3)3·4H2O (10 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cu­(NO3)3·3H2O (8 mg, 0.03 mmol), CBDA (4 mg, 0.01 mmol), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 0.5 mL), N-methylformamide (NMF, 0.5 mL), deionized water (H2O, 0.5 mL) and HNO3 (350 uL, 2.8 mL 18 mol L–1 HNO3 in 10 mL DMA) was sealed in a glass bottle and then heated in the oven at 90 °C for 24 h. After finishing this series of operations, the blue block-shaped crystals of In/Cu-CBDA were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried (yield: 73%, based on CBDA). It is worth mentioning that one-pot solvothermal synthesis of In/Cu-CBDA must consist of three types of solvents DMF, NMF, and H2O. Any combination of these two solvents (DMF-NMF, DMF-H2O, NMF-H2O) does not give rise to the product. Hence, the reaction solvent is of vital importance for one-pot solvothermal synthesis of heterometallic MOFs.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of In/Cu-CBDA 

The mixture of In(NO3)3⋅4H2O (10 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cu(NO3)3⋅3H2O (8 mg, 0.03 mmol), CBDA (4 mg, 0.01 mmol), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 0.5 mL), N-methylformamide (NMF, 0.5 mL), deionized water (H2O, 0.5 mL) and HNO3 (350 uL, 2.8 mL 18 mol L-1 HNO3 in 10 mL DMA) was sealed in a glass bottle and then heated in the oven at 90 °C for 24 h. After finishing this series of operations, the blue block-shaped crystals of In/Cu-CBDA were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and air-dried (yield: 73%, based on CBDA). It is worth mentioning that one-pot solvothermal synthesis of In/Cu-CBDA must consist of three types of solvents DMF, NMF, and H2O. Any combination of these two solvents (DMF-NMF, DMF-H2O, NMF-H2O) does not give rise to the product. Hence, the reaction solvent is of vital importance for one-pot solvothermal synthesis of heterometallic MOFs.

cln_elements.content:
The diffraction peaks position of the powder XRD spectrum of the compound obtained from the experiments are in good agreement with the simulated ones, indicating the synthesized compounds are pure phase (Figure S3). Next, the diffraction peaks of the experimental XRD spectra of the synthetic samples immersed in different solvents with low boiling points (acetone, acetonitrile, acetone, and methanol), exposed to air at room temperature for 24 h and 7 days and heated up to 150 °C air atmosphere for 5 h are consistent with the simulated spectra. Furthermore, in order to give more accurate information about the chemical stability of the framework, a C3H8 adsorption measurement has been tested before and after exposure to air (d and Figure S6). The maximum adsorption capacity is very close. It is proved that the crystal structure has outstanding stability in different organic solvents, air atmosphere, and high temperature. The presented good stability of framework is due to the strong coordination bond In-COOH based on HSAB theory ( and Figure S4). In addition, thermogravimetry is another method to characterize structural stability. It is the thermogravimetric curve of In/Cu-CBDA under the atmospheric environment (Figure S5). TGA of In/Cu-CBDA shows that the compound weightlessness can be divided into two steps. The first step of weightlessness is between 30 and 142 °C, and the weight loss rate is about 37.7%. Weight loss at this stage is mainly attributed to the removal of guest molecules and coordination water molecules. Then continual heat results in the collapse of the framework of the compound and the high thermal decomposition of the organic ligands, and the weight loss is about 23.1%.

Gas Adsorption and Separation of <bold>In/Cu-CBDA</bold>

To characterize the permanent porosity property of In/Cu-CBDA, we operated the N2 adsorption and desorption test at the temperature of 77 K. Before the gas adsorption experiment, we pretreated the as-synthesized sample. First, the low boiling point organic solvent acetone was used to obtain the acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA, ensuring that the high boiling point solvents in the structure were replaced completely by acetone. Second, the samples of acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA were withdrawn under dynamic vacuum heat at 90 °C for 10 h to get the activated In/Cu-CBDA. As shown in , the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of In/Cu-CBDA express a typical type-I adsorption curve which proves its microporous property. The absorption capacity of saturated N2 is 302 cm3 (STP) g–1, and the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir specific surface areas are calculated to be 990 and 1169 m2 g–1, respectively. The BET surface area of In/Cu-CBDA is lower than PMOFs based on a CBDA ligand and Cu paddlewheel, such as JLU-Liu46-47 (1787 and 1800 m2 g–1), but significantly higher than many heterometallic MOFs In/Tb-CBDA (782 m2 g–1), [In3O­(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]·n(solv) (In/Pd, 795 m2 g–1) and BUT-52 (In/Cu, 358 m2 g–1). The theoretical pore volume is 1.13 cm3/g, calculated based on the crystal structure. However, the experimental pore volume (0.47 cm3/g) is relatively low. This may be attributed to the fact that the partial window size of the cage structure is too small, which hinders the exchange of guest molecules with EtOH, resulting in an incomplete sample activation.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Characterization and Properties of In/Cu-CBDA 

The diffraction peaks position of the powder XRD spectrum of the compound obtained from the experiments are in good agreement with the simulated ones, indicating the synthesized compounds are pure phase (Figure S3). Next, the diffraction peaks of the experimental XRD spectra of the synthetic samples immersed in different solvents with low boiling points (acetone, acetonitrile, acetone, and methanol), exposed to air at room temperature for 24 h and 7 days and heated up to 150 °C air atmosphere for 5 h are consistent with the simulated spectra. Furthermore, in order to give more accurate information about the chemical stability of the framework, a C3H8 adsorption measurement has been tested before and after exposure to air (d and Figure S6). The maximum adsorption capacity is very close. It is proved that the crystal structure has outstanding stability in different organic solvents, air atmosphere, and high temperature. The presented good stability of framework is due to the strong coordination bond In-COOH based on HSAB theory ( and Figure S4). In addition, thermogravimetry is another method to characterize structural stability. It is the thermogravimetric curve of In/Cu-CBDA under the atmospheric environment (Figure S5). TGA of In/Cu-CBDA shows that the compound weightlessness can be divided into two steps. The first step of weightlessness is between 30 and 142 °C, and the weight loss rate is about 37.7%. Weight loss at this stage is mainly attributed to the removal of guest molecules and coordination water molecules. Then continual heat results in the collapse of the framework of the compound and the high thermal decomposition of the organic ligands, and the weight loss is about 23.1%.

Gas Adsorption and Separation of In/Cu-CBDA 

To characterize the permanent porosity property of In/Cu-CBDA, we operated the N2 adsorption and desorption test at the temperature of 77 K. Before the gas adsorption experiment, we pretreated the as-synthesized sample. First, the low boiling point organic solvent acetone was used to obtain the acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA, ensuring that the high boiling point solvents in the structure were replaced completely by acetone. Second, the samples of acetone-exchanged In/Cu-CBDA were withdrawn under dynamic vacuum heat at 90 °C for 10 h to get the activated In/Cu-CBDA. As shown in , the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of In/Cu-CBDA express a typical type-I adsorption curve which proves its microporous property. The absorption capacity of saturated N2 is 302 cm3 (STP) g-1, and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir specific surface areas are calculated to be 990 and 1169 m2 g-1, respectively. The BET surface area of In/Cu-CBDA is lower than PMOFs based on a CBDA ligand and Cu paddlewheel, such as JLU-Liu46-47 (1787 and 1800 m2 g-1), but significantly higher than many heterometallic MOFs In/Tb-CBDA (782 m2 g-1), [In3O(L)1.5(H2O)2Cl]⋅n(solv) (In/Pd, 795 m2 g-1) and BUT-52 (In/Cu, 358 m2 g-1). The theoretical pore volume is 1.13 cm3/g, calculated based on the crystal structure. However, the experimental pore volume (0.47 cm3/g) is relatively low. This may be attributed to the fact that the partial window size of the cage structure is too small, which hinders the exchange of guest molecules with EtOH, resulting in an incomplete sample activation.

metadata.title:
A Polyhedron-Based Heterometallic MOF Constructed
by HSAB Theory and SBB Strategy: Synthesis, Structure, and Adsorption
Properties
